summary: This FBI Significant Case Notification from June 28, 2019, details the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for sex trafficking of minors. It summarizes the 2005-2007 Florida investigation, the controversial 2007 non-prosecution agreement, and the new 2018-2019 investigation by the Southern District of New York (SDNY) leading to a planned sealed indictment and arrest. The document outlines Epstein's modus operandi, his properties, and the investigative plan moving forward.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure accused of sexually abusing and sex trafficking dozens of minor girls from approximately 2002-2005 in Florida and the mid-2000s in New York, paying them for massages that turned sexual.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: Former United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, later U.S. Secretary of Labor
persons.context: As U.S. Attorney in 2007, he met with Epstein's attorneys and approved a non-prosecution agreement for Epstein, a decision that garnered significant media attention during his Senate confirmation hearing for Secretary of Labor.

connections.description: Epstein's attorneys met with Acosta, then U.S. Attorney, leading to a non-prosecution agreement for Epstein in 2007.

events.title: Initial Florida Investigation Opened
events.description: West Palm Beach Police Department and FBI Miami initiated an investigation after parents reported Epstein sexually abused their daughter from 2002-2005. The investigation included interviews with approximately 35 victims and a search of Epstein's Florida residence.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Negotiated
events.description: After meetings between Epstein's attorneys and U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta, Epstein was offered a non-prosecution agreement requiring him to plead guilty to state solicitation charges.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty in Florida state court to soliciting prostitution. He was sentenced to 18 months in jail, served approximately 13 months in a work-release facility.

events.title: SDNY/FBI NY Case Initiation
events.description: FBI New York initiated a case after SDNY contacted them regarding several victims sexually abused by Epstein in New York in the mid-2000s.

events.title: Planned Sealed Indictment
events.description: SDNY tentatively planned to charge Epstein under a sealed indictment with two counts of sex trafficking of children and conspiracy to engage in human trafficking.

keyFacts: The 2005-2007 Florida investigation involved approximately 35 underage victims, recruited from local high schools, who were paid $200-$1,000 for sexual activity with Epstein.

A 2007 non-prosecution agreement, negotiated after Epstein's attorneys met with U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta, allowed Epstein to plead guilty only to state solicitation charges in 2008, serving about 13 months in a work-release jail.
The new SDNY investigation, initiated in December 2018, focused on victims abused by Epstein in New York in the mid-2000s, with victims as young as 14.
Epstein and co-conspirators used assistants to contact minors by phone to arrange 'massages' and coerced some victims to recruit other minor girls, paying the recruiters.
SDNY planned to file a sealed indictment on July 2, 2019, and file a lis pendens to initiate seizure of Epstein's Manhattan residence, reportedly the largest private residence in Manhattan.
